6.27.text:
and this is Poems
From The Field,

8.98.text:
a Web series from
Pioneer Digital Studios,

12.01.text:
that uses poetry to explore
with richness and depth,

15.68.text:
the creative and spiritual
lives of rural Minnesotans.

27.03.text:
My guest today is Poet
and Artist Edie Barrett,

30.66.text:
whose nest sculptures use
natural and found materials

34.47.text:
to explore our connection
with the prairie.

37.50.text:
She'll be reading her
poem, The Camisole.

44.31.text:
- I hand wash the antique camis,
then hang it on the line.

49.72.text:
I watch it gently
blow in the wind,

55.19.text:
The prairie breeze touches
each thread, each memory,

58.82.text:
the hard work, the
heartache, the hard-headed.

62.86.text:
Open to adventure, she
willingly came here.

66.07.text:
She arrived to the
vast open prairie,

68.53.text: her dreams lit by the stars,

73.74.text:
By the sparkling lake,
honking geese, pounding rain,

82.32.text:
Her dreams swirled, twisted
and turned with the wind.

85.95.text:
Wind that traveled
for miles and miles,

87.65.text:
stopping at nothing, but never
arriving to its destination.

92.26.text:
Only tuckering
out with a whisper

97.76.text:
Like a tenacious bird, building
a nest of grass and straw,

101.30.text:
hope, and promise, she
too trusted in nature,

105.14.text:
and her place in all
things wild and untamed.

113.15.text:
- (Lauren) Edie Barrett lives
in Ortonville, Minnesota.

116.25.text:
The inspiration
for her poem struck

118.72.text:
after a visit to her
local antique store

121.59.text:
in search of materials
for a sculpture.

124.89.text:
- Well usually when
I do nest sculptures,

127.76.text:
I am working with
driftwood, and you know,

132.43.text:
and last year I wasn't
finding anything,

134.83.text:
so I, I was, I was
trying to just like open

140.84.text:
and so I went to
this antique shop,

142.58.text:
and I was actually looking
for an old baptismal gown

146.35.text:
that I could create a nest
in that and there wasn't any,

149.01.text:
but what there was,
was this collection of

154.72.text:
And so I bought one,
and I wasn't sure how

156.96.text:
it was gonna translate,
but I literally did

160.29.text:
I literally did hang
it out on my line.

164.46.text:
And I have to tell you,
there is something,

178.84.text:
You're probably gonna
have to cut this--

180.28.text:
- Take the time, take
the time you need,

193.69.text:
- I will just watch the
sheets blow on the line,

196.53.text:
and it's like, I don't
know what it is about that.

202.17.text:
it's like the wind has
a form of expression.

207.97.text:
- And of course it does
in the trees too but

210.64.text:
I don't know, there's
just something in that,

212.31.text:
just sometimes it's
just a gentle billow,

215.48.text:
and then other times
it's like flapping and

220.19.text:
I don't know what it is
about the clothesline.

222.59.text:
- I think it, I think what
exactly what you just said,

226.36.text:
is that we don't,
you know what's that

229.46.text:
we don't even see the wind,
we just see what it like

231.96.text:
does to things, so the
clothesline is this way to like

241.47.text:
- And then to go to
bed when you have had

244.58.text:
those sheets on the
line, or your nightgown,

247.28.text:
the pillowcases,
it's just like being

253.25.text:
and there's really
nothing like it.

255.82.text:
- Oh, that gives me
goosebumps thinking about

258.79.text:
just like the little
particles somehow like

263.86.text:
- To the sheet and the
wind and all that just

267.83.text:
welcoming you while
you're, you're sleeping.

271.77.text:
whenever I go into bed
after, after all these things

274.14.text: have been on the line it's like,

275.61.text:
it's like wow, I, I
feel it, I smell it,

281.01.text:
So I literally did wash
the camisoles by hand.

283.75.text:
I literally did hang
them on the line,

291.22.text: I guess what I was struck by is,

295.63.text: they too washed them by hand.

297.80.text:
They too hung them on
the clothesline to dry.

302.47.text:
watched them blow
in the wind and,

305.47.text:
it was like this really
intriguing lineage

309.01.text:
of this feminine line of
what it means to live here.

313.68.text:
And I do have a intrigue
with the women who came here,

320.35.text:
you know, in the late 1800s,
of what it took to be here,

324.49.text:
I mean what courage and
the tenacity, and the grit,

330.30.text: you know, because you know it's,

334.17.text:
are a little challenging
for us with all our

341.97.text:
So I just, I think maybe
some things haven't changed,

346.51.text:
maybe that prairie
wind hasn't changed,

349.32.text:
the honking geese, the
diamonds on the lake,

354.32.text:
the night stars, I
mean those things,

361.13.text:
Time has changed, but those
have remained fairly consistent.

366.43.text:
- And the other thing
that struck me is

367.87.text:
sometimes the wind
does take things.
